awd_titl_txt: Investigating the Benefits of Using Worked Examples to Improve Mathematical Explanations for Students Who Struggle
awd_abstract_narration:
When students explain their solution approaches in mathematics, they are able to make linkages with prior knowledge, build new insights, and deepen their understanding of the mathematics they are learning. Students with mathematics difficulties (those performing below the 25th percentile) struggle to articulate their understanding of mathematical principles as they explain their solution approaches. Learning and understanding fractions in upper elementary school is especially challenging for students and often impedes learning for students as they advance in middle and high school mathematics. The purpose of the project is to improve mathematical explanations for students who struggle in mathematics, specifically with fractions. To accomplish this, the project will investigate the benefits of worked examples (i.e., already worked-out problems) as a mechanism to improve explanations for students who struggle. The project will develop worked example materials focused on fractions concepts for use with students with mathematics difficulties in Grade 5 and examine whether this approach to instruction enhances students’ mathematical explanations during intervention. 

The proposed project consists of three phases: development work, two short-duration randomized controlled trials (RCTs), and a feasibility pilot study followed by a multi-site RCT. First, the team will develop various types of worked examples (correct vs. incorrect solutions; one vs. two solutions) that address critical fractions concepts and operations in Grade 5 standards. Researchers will then conduct two short-duration RCTs to determine which worked example types are most promising for developing explanations for students with mathematics difficulties. Finally, worked example materials will be further developed and embedded as an instructional component into a previously validated fractions intervention. Intervention lessons will be examined in a feasibility pilot, which will be followed by a multi-site RCT. Eighty eligible students will be randomly assigned to receive small-group fractions intervention with worked examples or business-as-usual control. Student data will include measures of fractions concepts and procedures and assessments of written and verbal explanations. Assessments of working memory and attention will also be included. Implementation data will be collected using fidelity of treatment instruments and the CLASS observation system. Data analysis procedures involve a two-level hierarchical model and will explicitly account for the nesting of students in small instructional groups in the treatment condition but not in the control condition. A moderator analysis will be conducted by adding the interaction of condition with prior fractions knowledge, working memory, and attention.  This project is supported by the EHR Core Research Program (ECR) which supports fundamental research on STEM teaching and learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Purpose: Fractions represent a significant challenge in mathematical development, primarily due to their departure from the more intuitive, whole-number concepts learned earlier in elementary school. With contemporary mathematics standards emphasizing student explanations and conceptual understanding, students who are struggling to learn fractions need additional support to grasp this complex topic. Supplemental fractions intervention addressing student explanations and foundational fractions concepts, such as fractions magnitude, is one way to provide this needed support. The goal of this project, therefore, was to examine a new intervention component, using worked examples (i.e., pre-solved problems), to enhance explanations of fractions concepts for Grade 5 students with mathematics difficulties (MD, i.e., performing below the 35th percentile).

Development: A set of worked examples were developed for students to analyze and explain. Content of the worked examples focused on evaluating the relative magnitude of fractions, and on concepts underpinning addition and subtraction of fractions. Both correct and incorrect solution methods were illustrated on the worked examples, so that students had opportunities to not only explain concepts supporting correct strategies, but also to identify and explain potential misconceptions leading to inaccurate methods. A Verbal Explanations measure and scoring rubric were also developed for the project.

Two experimental studies were conducted. Study 1 explored whether using worked examples to enhance explanations for students with MD was effective and also tested whether worked examples that illustrated a mix of correct and incorrect solution methods were more beneficial than those with only correct solutions. Study 2 examined impacts of fractions intervention with embedded worked examples on fractions learning and explanations for Grade 5 students with MD.

Study 1

Design: Through a small-scale RCT, 49 students were randomly assigned to receive worked example intervention with a mix of correct and incorrect solutions (n = 16), worked example intervention with only correct solutions (n = 16), or business-as-usual control (n = 17). Each intervention included eight lessons

Findings: The main outcome was the Verbal Explanations measure (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.78). To understand if worked examples supported explanations, the first analysis combined treatment groups, demonstrating significant results compared to the control group (g = 1.98, p < .000). To understand whether correct and incorrect solution methods were more useful, the second analysis contrasted the two treatment groups, demonstrating that a mix of correct and incorrect solutions was more beneficial than correct solutions only (g = 1.42, p = .018).

Study 2

Intervention: The set of worked examples found most effective from Study 1 were embedded into adapted TransMath (ATM; also funded by NSF, Award 1535214; Jayanthi et al., 2021), a comprehensive fractions intervention targeting Grades 4 and 5 standards. ATM previously demonstrated positive and significant findings on measures of fractions proficiency and understanding (g = 0.66–0.78). ATM included key instructional features for mathematics intervention, including explicit instruction; concrete and semi-concrete representations; number lines; accurate mathematical language; and written explanations. Worked examples were strategically placed into lessons to review previously taught concepts so that explanations, rather than new learning, were the focus of the activity. 

Design: Grade 5 students were screened; students performing at or below the 35th percentile on a fractions assessment were eligible to participate. Eligible students were randomly assigned to receive ATM fractions intervention with worked examples (36 lessons) or business-as-usual control. The analytic sample included 99 students (n = 48 for treatment; n = 51 for control).

Findings: Results indicated that intervention students significantly outperformed comparison students on both verbal explanations (g = 0.89) and written explanations (g = 1.11), the central focus of the study. Furthermore, intervention students significantly outperformed their peers on a range of measures assessing fractions magnitude understanding and general fractions knowledge (g = 0.78–0.86), which replicated findings from Jayanthi et al. (2021). We explored whether incoming fractions knowledge, working memory, or attention moderated impacts for conceptual explanations or fractions proficiency. Results identified no significant moderators, indicating that the intervention was effective for students regardless of these factors.  

The positive and significant results for explanations in both studies underscored the effectiveness of worked examples showcasing both correct and incorrect solution methods in improving explanations among Grade 5 students with MD. These findings were in line with prior findings using worked examples to develop mathematical explanations for typical learners (Booth et al., 2015; Durkin et al., 2017). Contemporary mathematics standards emphasize students’ explanations, and these results indicate that using worked examples to develop explanations is a promising instructional practice for students with MD.
